comments.commentBody: Yup, despite loads of neighborhood resistance it has basically gained all necessary approvals to open. Whether the human race survives or is destroyed, it will be by our own hand.
Yep, I can guarantee some Senators or Congresspeople will try to score political points with this and will interrogate him in their usual self-righteous, loud style.

No, this guy actually DID his JOB. That's the diff.
He specifically did NOT tell everyone involved in officially coordinated misbehavior NOT to let the press or Congress know, as we already know Lois Lerner actively did.
When a conspirator is caught telling others to follow the omerta', it's all over but the sentencing phases.

It appears Dr. Frieden did the right thing. I predict his reward will be to be hauled before a House Committee and grilled relentlessly without the opportunity to answer the accusations (excuse me questions) that the Members will ask in their usual McCathyesque, self-righteous style. They will likely spend more money on a Congressional witch hunt than is needed to actually alleviate the problem at the labs. Anyway, we all know it is President Obama's fault, just check Faux News.

You have such a low risk of being contaminated, even if you were to live on Clifton Way. Oh right CDC bought up the final 17 houses and 17 acres of houses on Clifton Way over 15 years ago. The Closest homes are on Houston mill, nothing is going to reach them. Any thing worked on in the BSL -4 lab. BLD 17. Goes through fume hoods, and multi levels hepa filtration located in the interstitial space above the actual lab before it even reaches the exterior. The BSL-4 labs have multiple levels of back-ups. The doors and multiple entry locks that require shower in and shower out, before you get in a space suit.

Most anthrax and flu is only worked on in BSL -3 labs. Under fume hoods, and negative pressure rooms, down controlled hallways that only laboratory staff have access too.

Since you have live in Atlanta make an appointment for a tour of the CDC museum it is in Bldg 19 ( or 20 or 21) It has a mock up of what the different BSL labs are like. It is interesting. My 19 year old remembers when I took her on a tour of the museum and she got to see the spacesuit the lab workers wear.

Not sure I should dignify this comment with a reply, but here goes. Integration and diversity can both good, even at the same time. Integration doesn't mean that you must marry someone of a different race so you can produce children of the right shade of brown. It means everyone should be accepted as similarly valuable. And diversity is not just about color. It's also about ethnicity (country/culture of origin), economics, religion or lack thereof, lifestyle, values, and practices of various groups being valued. We don't have to be the same to be OK together.

My son's fiance is half Czech and half Japanese, but all American. He is a very white all American. I guess they are an integrated couple, but as they are both middle class both by upbringing and according to their current status, they are not very diverse.

It was known by the FBI by the Monday after the Oct. 12, 2011 anthrax attack that the Anthrax, came from a Federal Lab. This was the Lab that, it came from. The suicide was an admission of guilt. All the strains of the anthrax the government had could be tracked to its labs, surprise.

It is just like people don't want to believe their employers have key stoke software on their work computers, and have had it for over 15 years and know what they do besides work.

At least it appears the CDC informed workers about the incidents. NIH workers were not informed about the smallpox's being found in vials in storage. They found out in the PRESS!
http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2014/07/10/employees-never-notified-about-...

Yes, it is real medical research.  But much of it has been driven by the availability of money from NIH, DOD, etc. expressly for biothreat research - to the detriment of research on other diseases, particularly other infectious disease pathogens and drug resistance.
I love that you all are doing this! Hoist a beverage for me. I'll be there in spirit.

Every large car manufacturer builds off of international platforms.

It costs a ton of money to develop platforms for production. When you have one that is successful, you have to spread out the R&D and development costs.

This article isn’t complete without mentioning GM’s crucial decision to hold on to its Opel division.
Most of Buick’s vehicles now use platforms which were developed by Opel, and several Buick models are simply rebadged versions of current Opel models.
1. The small crossover SUV Buick Encore is a reworked Opel Mokka.
2. The compact Buick Verano was developed off the Opel-created Delta II platform (i.e. the Opel Astra 4-door.)
3. The mid-sized Buick Regal is a rebranded Opel Insignia.
4. The LaCrosse is based on a stretched version of Opel’s Epsilon II platform (basically a stretched Opel Insignia.)
This is the more complete story of Buick’s success.

Yeah. They keep GMC which sell the exact same thing as Chevy but cut Saturn which is a youth / budget brand. I guess it has something to do with Saturn plants not being unionized and GMC is. Saturn's unique and well selling L was cut mainly because UAW don't want the brand to succeed. Lots of back door politics.

At its end, Saturn had actually already begun the practice which I mentioned in an earlier comment is the strategy that Buick is now employing; namely using reworked/rebadged Opel platforms and models.

1. The compact Saturn Astra was a rebadged Opel Astra.
2. The Saturn Aura was based on the platform for the Opel Vectra.
3. The compact crossover SUV Saturn Vue was a rebadged Opel Antara.

There were probably a number of marketing reasons why GM decided to go with Buick and drop the Saturn division (along with Pontiac.) Certainly Buick’s already strong presence in China was a major factor.

Why did they abandon Saturn? Saturn owners were loyal. I traded in my previous one at 250,000 miles and the one I own now has !58,000 and is still going strong. I'd buy another if they still made them.
I'm almost old enough to buy a Buick at 63 but I'll stick with my Mazda CX-5 that will run circles around a Encore while getting better MPG

Like Argentina, there will be claims by bond holders/insurers against Detroit even a decade from now.

If even guaranteed revenue streams, such as special revenue bonds and lockbox arrangements, are invalidated, Detroit and other marginal cities will have to pay dearly to issue debt in the future.

The Federal courts need to think very carefully about the precedents they are creating. Unfortunately, Detroit is 85% black, and the optics of ruling in favor of financial institutions holding its debt, make it very difficult to make an impartial ruling.

I think there's truth to what AAF says. i grew up a WASP in a new haven suburb and left for 20 years. I thought when i came back things would have changed. but not much has changed. white blue collar towns with no jews - still the same, mostly jewish towns kept separate - still the same, mostly black "underclass" - still the same, white upper middle class towns where non-whites walking around get stared at - still the same. There are some really great things about southern connecticut, but religious, racial and cultural intermingling is not one of them.
What? The demographics of the projects in 1959 were most likely white? That's entirely false.
The author does not mention the demographics of the projects in 1959, when the fence was put up.  There is a pretty good chance it was mostly white then.

I still remember keenly an event of 40+ years ago trying pot for the second or third time while listening to The Jefferson Airplane at appropriate volume.  It was one of the most remarkable musical experiences of my life.  The best description I could ever come up with was that it was like having binoculars on my ears; I could hear and analyze and appreciate all the harmonies simultaneously.  Unfortunately, this was never repeated, and 20 years later I had a terrifying psychic experience with more modern pot that prompted me to swear off it forever....alas.

Yes, we modern folk are prone to simplistically explain or explain away anything that doesn't fit in our worldview. We seem content to explain rather than live life -- even or especially when we encounter something new to us. See how some of the other comments above explain or dismiss quickly.
Science is third person perspective, a stepping back from living. It does provide useful data, but we do have, are faced with, first person perspective moments that science can't live for us. Thanks to Dick for sharing one.
Love the image of binoculars on your ears! Perfect, vivid description. Thanks for brightening my day a bit with this.

I recall in '69, when spending the summer in Berkeley with my brother, that we had various hallucinogenic experiences. For me at least, it did not involve hallucinations but rather especially in nature, seeing things more deeply and vividly than I ever had.

In our modern world and 'rational' culture, there is often mistrust of anything not scientifically provable, even in medical research anecdotal information is generally disregarded or seen of lower importance than carefully constructed studies.

Yet how can each of us explain fully those moments of clarity when we see a sunset, as my brother and I did, which revealed itself more beautifully and profoundly as the minutes passed, minutes which in the end nearly felt like hours, as our attention was so focused and the natural world so compelling, so present.

In Buddhism, there is talk of our adult human minds being like 'monkey minds', constantly jumping from one thought to another, very often preoccupied and not living in the present moment. It does not take drugs to reveal to us those things most meaningful. Whether in the throes of romantic passion with someone we love, or running, just running along a path on Mount Tamalpais, there are moments we don't forget, the important ones, the ones with vibrant and enduring meaning.

jack, the unwed mother rate was 5% in 1960 and in 2011 it had risen to 40%. 70% for blacks, 53% for hispanics, and 29% for whites per the government statistics. unwed mothers rates are inversely proportional to education and income levels no matter what race or color you are. www.census.gov/ prod/2013. i didn't check the rest of your numbers. i live in an integrated neighborhood, but we all own our homes and it's a good area. sometimes a person takes better care of their own stuff rather than government property. government housing projects usually bring down home prices and lower the number of public education students in that area. i suggest we try to get everyone back to work, a rising tide lifts all boats. some people were given great deals on houses in my area and the ability to own them for much better prices and a shorter time period than i was in my neighborhood but that fell flat because they weren't really able to even afford those prices and were allowed to purchase anyway. those people are all gone now and their savings are gone with them. it was a disservice to them. some times well meaning programs have the reverse effect. that is where most republican and democrat voters disagree, both want to help, but they can't agree what will work best.

This story does not address why New Haven, in the first place, put the public housing project in a corner of New Haven about as far as possible from its signature institution, Yale University.  Blame Hamden, but the real story in New Haven today is the same as it was in the 1800s when New Haven residents violently opposed siting a school for blacks in the city.

" I don't blame people get used to the fence, find it comforting against that unknown fear"

The fear is not petty or of the unknown. Don't get too comfortable repeating clichés.
The fear is of an increase in crime that people in this city know firsthand.

You apparently haven't seen or have ignored the reports that say that a huge percentage of the people that ended up enrolling were under 35, and that 90% of the people surveyed were at least middling happy with their choice of doctors. About 75% were able to keep their current doctors under their plans.

In addition, now that we have so many people paying for their insurance instead of getting health care for "free" at emergency rooms, the cost will decrease substantially.

The LeBron who left was immature, selfish, obsessed with winning a ring, a selfish player, and had decided to ignore his roots.  The LeBron who is returning is mature, balanced, a team player and now understands the importance of loyalty to his home town.  The LeBron who left is not the LeBron who has returned.  He's gone from widely unpopular to widely respected.  Cleveland hasn't changed.  LeBron has.

Watching sports on TV or live is a pastime. Some people are far more enthusiastic than others. That is their prerogative.  Lebron James returning to Cleveland is not going to solve all this countries ills. Pontificating about it on a internet message board isn't going to solve anything either, other than to provide a psychological salve to the societal betterment campaign you are raging on your keyboard. This is a good thing for Cleveland. The city is experiencing a major downtown Renaissance, the sports scene( not just basketball) has a bright future and Cleveland was just chosen to host the 2016 GOP Convention. The city has been a national punching bag for many, many years. Just let them have their moment in the sun without providing the mostly cloudy with rain forecast that most likely pervades your everyday thinking.

Don't forget that somewhere a specious point is haughtily made as proof of superiority while across the world women and children are being slaughtered as a result of fools acting is if specious points were profound truths.
What does this have to do with LeBron James?

Man decides to throw balls into a basket in another city. When he speaks, it turns out he remembers growing up there. When he ponders, he realizes that change can be hard. Many people look forward to spending hundreds of hours watching television coverage of this man. Most believe the colors this man wears directly affects their possibilities for happiness.

Somewhere else, a child looks for his father, and finds only locked doors and trails of beer bottles.
The best news since Otto Graham.

The loss of a second game is not a problem, merely a result. The pressure to not lose may be more intense than the pressure to win. This match is the crucible in which character is truly tested.
That's worth playing. That's worth watching. Play on.
Lots of teams lose two in a row or three in a row and are out and they never get out of the group stage. It is totally inconsistent to suggest no 3/4 place game on that basis.
Please note that the USMNT lost two in a row. It's part and parcel of the tournament format.

The biggest problem with the 3rd place game is that the loser of the game will end up with 2 consecutive losses to finish a tournament, in which they reached the semifinal.  This is needlessly disappointing.

The American State Department organized and sponsored the coup d'état in Ukraine. That's a historical fact with plenty of leaked diplomatic communications to support it. But never mind that, after all orchestrating chaos abroad is what Washington does (e.g. Syria, Venezuela, etc.)

My larger point is the following. The moment an ethnic Russian population is conquered by a NATO-sponsored military on the very border of Russia, the tribe of Neocons in Washington (Hillary Clinton, McCain, et al.) will take away but one lesson: They'll set their eyes on Russia itself, with potentially disastrous consequences for Europe and the world.

What I'm left wondering after reading this piece is how it affects one to go through life so ruthlessly and exclusively focused on judging the looks of others, to make it your business to do so.   Did it make her stay within a more or less rarified world of beautiful people?  Could she see beauty in less conventional faces?  Did she ever offer her thoughts on how great beauty affected one's life, or experiences?  What did she think of her own looks?  How did she treat the not-beautiful people in her world?  When one's whole life is based around how people look, how does that affect their relationships?
